did.unittitle: Political Women in Connecticut Project Records

repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

did.abstract: Transcripts of the oral history project "The Political Activities of Fully Enfranchised Connecticut Women," undertaken by the Center for Oral History at the University of Connecticut in 1981. The records consist of twenty-one interview transcripts, covering the lives and activities of Connecticut's female activists and legislators during the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Political Activities of Fully Enfranchised Connecticut Women project was undertaken by the Center for Oral History at the University of Connecticut, in conjunction with the University's Women's Studies Program in 1981. The twenty-one interviews were conducted by Joyce Pendery and Carole Nichols with women who were political activists in Connecticut after suffrage was granted by the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. The interviewees include female activists who participated in Connecticut's women's suffrage movement, as well as female legislators and their careers in Connecticut politics during the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s.. The interviews were the basis for a series of public radio broadcasts and an article in the 1983 Oral History Review.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains twenty-one transcripts of oral history interviews conducted by the Center for Oral History at the University of Connecticut. The interviews were conducted with women who were active in political office, and/or community service, in Connecticut immediately after the ratification of the 19th Amendment. Each interview describes the interviewee's education, family, and political activities. Each folder also contains data sheets on the interviewee, providing age, place of birth, places of residence, parents' background, occupations, memberships in organizations, and other personal information. In addition to the transcripts, the collection includes scrapbooks created by Helen Kitchel and books on related topics. The transcripts are arranged alphabetically by the interviewee's last name. The women interviewed are as follows; Marion Yeaw Biglow, Virginia L. Blood, Emily Sophie Brown, Josephine E. Bryant, Edith Valet Cook, Ruth McIntire Dadourian, Helen A. Green, Stephanie Sulik Kamenski, Helen Binney Kitchel, Percy Maxim Lee, Eleanor H. Little, Laura Belle Reed McCoy, Margaret Nordhoff Morrison, Alice Emmons Parmelee, Edna Mary Purtell, Nancy Carnegie Rockefeller, Celia Duhan Rostow, Isabel Curtin Rylander, Hilda Crosby Standish, Hazel Thrall Sullivan, and Chase Going Woodhouse.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Copyright Information
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance and Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The materials in the collection were transferred by the Center for Oral History in 1984.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Political Women in Connecticut Project Records. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The scrapbooks were given by Ms. Kitchel to the Center for Oral History in support of her oral history.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of materials pertaining to various aspects of Connecticut history and the University, its history, administration, faculty, staff and students. Researchers should review the finding aid for the Center for Oral History Records for related information. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the Reading Room desk.
